byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Scott Shane from Washington, Alissa J. Rubin and Rukmini Callimachi from Paris; Andrew E. Kramer from Moscow; David D. Kirkpatrick from London; Isabel Kershner from Jerusalem; Laurie Goodstein from New York; and Thomas Erdbrink from Tehran.

abstract: Array of regional and world powers agree on need to unite against Islamic State, but devil remains in the details concerning how such a mission could be accomplished, and what potential consequences might be; topics at center of debate include fate of Syrian Pres Bashar al-Assad and Islamic reform.
lead_paragraph: Much of the world agrees the Islamic State must be crushed. But how that can be accomplished, and what the consequences may be, is more complicated.

headline.main: Experts Explain How Global Powers Can Smash ISIS
headline.print_headline: Envisioning How the Global Powers Can Smash a Brutal Enemy

snippet: Much of the world agrees the Islamic State must be crushed. But how that can be accomplished, and what the consequences may be, is more complicated.
